document.docOrigin: Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society 164 (3)
document.masterDocTitle: The Halticini of the world (Insecta: Heteroptera: Miridae: Orthotylinae): generic reclassification, phylogeny, and host plant associations

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The Halticini of the world (Insecta: Heteroptera: Miridae: Orthotylinae): generic reclassification, phylogeny, and host plant associations
Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society

subSubSection.paragraph: Diagnosis: Easily recognized by the following characters: strongly myrmecomorphic, with extreme staphylinoidy in females and most males; tall genae in both sexes; hemelytra in macropterous individuals without cuneus, membrane without cells.

caption.paragraph:
Figure 39. Scanning electron micrograph images of
Myrmecophyes alboornatus
(male). A, head and thorax, dorsal view; B, head, anteroventral view; C, head and thorax, lateral view; D, external efferent system of the metathoracic scent gland (MTG) and the metathoracic spiracle; E, detail of MTG evaporative bodies; F, tarsus; G, pygophore, posterior view; H, pygophore, ventral view.

Figure 40. Male and female genitalia of
Myrmecophyes alboornatus
. A, aedeagus, phallotheca removed; B, left paramere; C, right paramere; D, bursa copulatrix, dorsal view; E, first gonapophyses, ventral view; F, posterior wall.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diversity and distribution: Myrmecophyes
contains 29 species and has a Holarctic distribution, with a single species (
My. oregonensis
) restricted to the western USA and the remainder of species found in the Palaearctic region.

Included species:
Myrmecophyes acutifrons Bykov, 1971
Central Asia
